entry.et: Middle English screne, from Anglo-French escren, from Middle Dutch scherm; akin to Old High German skirm shield; probably akin to Sanskrit carman skin, kṛnāti he injures shear

def.dt: :a protective or ornamental device (as a movable partition) shielding an area from heat or drafts or from view
:something that shelters, protects, or hides: as
:a growth or stand of trees, shrubs, or plants
:a protective formation of troops, ships, or planes
:something that covers or disguises the true nature (as of an activity or feeling) his geniality is just a screen
:a maneuver in various sports (as basketball or ice hockey) whereby an opponent is legally impeded or the opponent's view of the play is momentarily blocked
:screen pass
:a perforated plate or cylinder or a meshed wire or cloth fabric usually mounted and used to separate coarser from finer parts
:a system for examining and separating into different groups
:a piece of apparatus designed to prevent agencies in one part from affecting other parts an optical screen
:a frame holding a usually metallic netting used especially in a window or door to exclude pests (as insects)
:a flat surface on which a picture or series of pictures is projected or reflected
:the surface on which the image appears in an electronic display (as in a television set, radar receiver, or computer terminal)
:the information displayed on a computer screen at one time
:a glass plate ruled with crossing opaque lines through which an image is photographed in making a halftone
:the motion-picture medium or industry
:to guard from injury or danger
:to give shelter or protection to with or as if with a screen
:to separate with or as if with a screen
:to shield (an opponent) from a play or from view of a play
:to pass (as coal, gravel, or ashes) through a screen to separate the fine part from the coarse
:to remove by a screen
:to examine usually methodically in order to make a separation into different groups
:to select or eliminate by a screening process
:to test or examine for the presence of something (as a disease) patients were screened for hepatitis
:to provide with a screen to keep out pests (as insects)
:to present (as a motion picture) for viewing on a screen
:to view the presentation of (as a motion picture)
:to present in a motion picture
:to appear on a motion-picture screen
:to provide a screen in a game or sport
:a recollection of early childhood that may be falsely recalled or magnified in importance and that masks another memory of deep emotional significance
:a forward pass in football to a receiver at or behind the line of scrimmage who is protected by a screen of blockers
:a computer program that usually displays various images on the screen of a computer that is on but not in use
:a short film sequence for assessing the ability or suitability of a person for a motion-picture role
:the motion picture medium often as contrasted to television a story adapted for the big screen
:a photographic technique in which a subject is filmed in front of a blue background so as to allow matte compositing of the film with other footage
:the blue background
:a Chinese lacquered folding screen
:a protective screen before a fireplace
